column10: b"b' SQL panel fix for locales that use comma as a decimal separator.'"

b'b\' I\\\'ve noticed this problem some time ago. "width_ratio" and "start_offset" were printed with comma as a separator (I use polish locale) and this confused CSS parser. I couldn\\\'t find a way to forcibly print a number in a dotted notation so I rolled out my own template filter.\''

b'b\' Quite mistakinbly I\\\'ve added another commit to this pull request. Is it still pullable properly? Anyway the second patch fixes another problem when a "djDebugLineChart" container is shifted with the "left" CSS property its width changes accordingly. Therefore the width of a "<strong>" inside must be scaled relatively to the remaining space.\''
b'b" Do you know what\'s actually being printed localized? Do ints automatically get localized in templates or is there some other magic?"'
b'b" I\'ve noticed that floating points numbers are localized here in Poland we use comma as a decimal separator
column11: but this is true for other countries as well (France I guess?)."'

b"b' An obvious moral from this bug is to be very careful when floating-point number is used in HTML attributes. :)'"
b"b' (urgent security problem) default _show_toolbar causes debug to leak to unprivileged IPs'"

This is _extremely_ bad and is completely against the documentation: "The default checks are that DEBUG must be set to True and the IP of the request must be in INTERNAL_IPS. " Please release an urgent fix for this by using:  \''

column11: but this is going to be a wontfix. Don\'t run DEBUG in production."'

b'b" May I ask what the reasoning is behind marking this as wontfix? I simply don\'t see why you would assume users want DDT shown to all requests
column11: just purely on debug being enabled. :S"'

column10: b'b" Just my two cents worth but
column11: changing documentation to get around bugs (especially when they related to security) is not very clever. DDT is a decent piece of code
column12: well written
column13: with a lot of  gone into it. You\'ve made a backwards incompatible change
column14: without changing major release numbers. Look at this from a purely logical point of view
column15: the decision of wontfix doesn\'t make any sense :X"'

column16: which is the current development version.\''

What kind of situation would you have DEBUG = True and not be accessing it from an "internal ip"? That\\\'s what I would define as a production environment.\''

column10: b'b" You are suggesting that all users should be privileged to have this information
column11: just because they have an internal IP? Sorry
column12: but no. If our testing department has internal IPs (which they do)
column13: they would also get to see this information. On top of this
column14: DDT adds significant page loading times when enabled
column15: so when testers test a change in dev (and ensure it isn\'t taking ages to load) they can\'t do this unless we push this to . (edit) I guess in smaller environments where you don\'t have many people  on the same code
column16: it won\'t make much of a difference. But for large environments like we are working on

column10: b"b' Rewrite features written in javascript in closure library'"
b'b\' Writring the javascript in closure would provide two improvements:Everyting is in a javascript closure
column11: so it\\\'s not possible to overlap with other librariesOnly what is needed is compiled so there is no "big" dependency to load. The major improvement would be to avoid any possible conflict with any other javascript that can be on the page where debugtoolbar is used. I would be glad to work on this
column12: if it has any chance to be included in the project. ref: url \''

column10: b'b\' I think you mix several things here. While I **do** think that having everything properly shielded from other code is the right thing to do
column11: I don\\\'t see how rewriting everything in Closure is a proper way to do this. Putting closures around everything is a feature of JavaScript the language
column12: not of the Closure compiler. Any conflicts with other libraries or "open" code is a bug and deserves a separate bug report each. So we have several tickets inside this one:1. **Conflicts with other libraries**: go for it
column13: but open a separate ticket for each problem.2. **Encapsulating code**: no problem per se
column14: but needs more details. A pull request for each problem would be nice
column15: but trying to put everything in a closure might be overkill.3. **Introducing Closure**: I would be against it
column16: but I\\\'m a noone in this project
column17: so open a separate ticket and let David decide.\''

column10: b'b" I understand your points
column11: they are vallid
column12: maybe a mailling list might have been a better place to talk about this
column13: I though it was agreed on github to discuss that way. I don\'t want to create several tickets since I think the bug is jQuery. I could rephrase my ticket: \\xc2\\xabjQuery is not the good tool for the job
column14: let\'s rewrite the javascript in closure library and ship the compiled code\\xc2\\xbb."'

column10: b'b" Hm
column11: I\'m not convinced that this is a good idea
column12: jQuery is a proven tool and the toolbar isolates its JavaScript code in the object and uses jQuery\'s function to further prevent spoiling the namespace. Closing as wontfix."'

column10: b'b" I\'m getting something like that too and it started all of a sudden. How did you resolve it?"'

b"b' It seemed to be because the content type on the page was json only (I was working on a django-powered json-based REST api at the time). The debug toolbar needs the body html tag to render correctly. The hack I used to get around this was to print the json object and wrap it in the required html tag when testing the REST api ( DEBUG=True)  The database error was due to some other complex middleware conflict that I could not resolve.'"

column10: b"b' Better support for 3rd party panels needing .'"

b'b" This is an idea I had long ago but apparently never wrote down. The idea was: imagine if the SQL panel were a 3rd party panel. The steps to integrate the panel would require both a debug toolbar setting to activate the panel but also a URL insertion to map a new URL to the view. My thought was we could adopt something similar to what the admin does where it allows custom admin URLs to be added. I think it\'s on the admin class or something. If panels had a similar mechanism to provide their own URLs and views
column11: that opens up more options for 3rd party panels to be able to do their own calls out to views for AJAX or the like."'

column10: b'b" Yes
column11: that\'s a good idea
column12: and built-in panels should use this API too."'

column10: b"b' Could someone submit a pull request?'"
b'b" I\'ll try to get one together this coming week."'
b"b' Disable Logging panel when DEBUG is set to False to prevent memory leaks'"
b'b" I upgraded django-debug-toolbar from 0.9.4. to 1.0.1
column11: and I noticed my application was quickly leaking memory even when  was set to False. Once I removed debug_toolbar from the list of applications
column12: the problem disappeared. Upon further investigation
column13: I found that LoggingPanel was quietly collecting all my log messages and never releasing them. This problem only occurs if the Django application is fully initialized (e.g. using runserver)
column14: since this causes the LoggingPanel to register its handlers. Here is a simple application that illustrates the problem: Run this application with the default debug_toolbar settings
column15: and then use \'top\' to watch the memory grow without bound. The problem appears that the LoggingPanel does not use the enable_instrumentation() function normally called by the middleware
column16: which does the DEBUG check beforehand. I think the simplest fix is to check if DEBUG is enabled before initializing the LogCollector. This pull request does just that
column17: and it appears to fix the issue. In addition
column18: I think we should consider a few other things: 1) Warn the user that under DEBUG mode
column19: memory used for log messages can grow without bounds (this might be true for other panels already). 2) Limit the  of messages stored (perhaps as a configuration option)."'

b"b' @aaugustin can you please review the changes?'"
b'b" Don\'t run context processors for redirect template."'
b"b' In certain configurations
column11: applying the context processors when rendering the redirect template can cause exceptions.  For example
column12: assume the folllowing Django settings: Further
column13: assume that sets an attribute on the request that tries to access.  If causes a redirect
column14: (e.g. as a result of the setting)
column15: the attribute that needs will never get set on the request.  Then when initializing the in order to render
column16: an exception will occur when tries to access the missing attribute. Since no context processors are needed to render the template
column17: avoid this problem by replacing with
column18: which does not apply context processors to the template context.'"

column10: b'b\' I don\\\'t see any problem here. In the setup the line telling that Django debug toolbar want\\\'s Django >= 1.7 must stay. This is the dependency. Pip is clever and try to install dependencies (for that reason we use PIP and not downloading packages manually and executing python  install on them). @BrunoDesthuilliers If your project is not ready for django 1.7 (which is current minor supported version not only from django-debug-toolbar but from Django itself) then you need to use  with your packages and versions to which it depends and to put because this is your dependency. I will vote this issue to be marked as "invalid".\''

b'b" @vstoykov  I\'m sorry but I have to disagree here. An add-on should in no way try to upgrade the host framework\'s version which is the responsability of the project\'s maintainer specially when this add-on is supposed to be a developper-only tool (I could eventually see the point for a full-blown CMS or E-Commerce application and even then...). FWIW django-debug-toolbar is the very first django app I\'ve seen that behave that way the others only document which django version each release supports
column11: and break if you install them on an unsupported one
column12: and as a Django dev that\'s what I expect. And yes
column13: switching to 1.3.2 is what I did (obviously). The issue here is not with the current django-debug-toolbar version not supporting django 1.6 but with it wanting to upgrade django not caring if it breaks my whole project."'

column10: b'b" django-debug-toolbar do not try to install newer version of Django. PIP is installing it because it sees that this is requirement which is not satisfied (this is how PIP works). When you install package and then when you run your project something fails you start wondering where is the problem in your code
column11: in the 3th party app code or something else. You can submit an issue because you think that something is broken until you realize that you are trying to use unsupported version. On the other hand when you install a package and it tries to upgrade some other package (mainly Django) you now know that obviously you are trying to use latest version of something which do not support your older version of Django. Your not seeing many (or other) packages to depends on Django 1.7 or greater right now because a lot of 3th party packages are trying to achieve greater backward compatibility and support Django versions to 1.4 or even lower. Probably the main problem is that support for lower versions of Django was dropped so soon (only 5 days after end of life of Django 1.4 the previous LTS)
column12: but the approach how it was done was right. A proper solution for the situation is probably more precise documentation about installing on different versions
column13: and advice for upgrading to newer Django. @BrunoDesthuilliers  I have one suggestion to you. Youse dev_ or requirements_ or something similar to describe all dependencies not needed for production bot only for development. This will be easier for you and your colleagues. @aaugustin I have one suggestion to you also. Think more before dropping support of older Django versions. I don\'t say that all Django versions from the beginning of time need to be supported
column14: but still only 5 days after end of life it\'s to soon."'

column10: b'b\' @vstoykov  I have one suggestion for you too : don\\\'t assume that peoples who disagree with you and state they are not packaging experts are noobies needing guidance ;)  Oh and I didn\\\'t wait for your "suggestion" to separate dev requirements from prod\\\'s requirements either believe it or else but it\\\'s not exactly my first Python project (nor the first Django one). The code stating that latest django-debug-toolbar requires django >= 1.7 is in django-debug-toolbar\\\'s code
column11: so yes practically speaking it actually is django-debug-toolbar that asks pip to upgrade django. You can sample other django reusable apps I just had a look at a couple ones from one of my project\\\'s requirements and very few (actually 2 out of 8) mention Django in the the  or  . Not enough for statistical evidence tough... Now wether it\\\'s a "good practice" or not is debatable but as far as I\\\'m concerned I fail to see how someone installing a django app in a project\\\'s venv would expect the app to work without django anyway. What I do not know is if there\\\'s a way to tell pip to refuse to install or issue a warning instead
column12: which would make much more sense. This being said you might be right about the point that the root problem here is dropping support for older Django versions a tad too soon **and** not clearly documenting supported versions.  \''

column10: b'b" @vstoykov I\'ve spent days on end discussing and thinking about how to handle backwards incompatible changes and version upgrades in Django and its ecosystem. Please don\'t assume that I made this change on a whim. When a Django version no longer receives security support
column11: it\'s very damaging to the community to maintain support for it in a popular application such as the debug-toolbar because it implies that it\'s reasonable to keep running that version and that implication comes from people who are supposed to know what they are doing. (That\'s just one reason) Let\'s get back to the original topic. In general pluggable Django applications don\'t make Django a requirement because it\'s fairly obvious that they only work with Django. There\'s no use case for doing and exepecting it to install (or upgrade) Django. The desirable behavior here is to warn the user if an incompatible version of Django is installed. Forcing the upgrade of Django is one way to warn but perhaps not the best one. Aborting the installation would work as well. Silently proceeding sounds bad -because the app will crash immediately."'

column10: b'b\' @BrunoDesthuilliers Ok I accepts your advice and I will try to not judge people too early :). About listing django as requirement in pluggable django applications if it says only yes it\\\'s obvious and unnecessary
column11: but adding version is good approach. It explicitly says which versions are supported. For developer executing  it\\\'s obvious that  do not want to upgrade Django right now but when this was happening this means that the code base is really out of date and eventually insecure and probably now is the time to think for upgrade.  There always a way for a workaround and print some warning on screen or even break but:1. If you missed that your django version are updated automatically
column12: probably you will miss the warning message also.2. If install process breaks because of dependancy
column13: why we use and and not  . Probably for the current situation there is no "best" solution because the problem is not in setup but in handling python packages at general. How given package which as plugin to bigger system can describe his compatibility and package manager (pip or easy_install) to handle this accordingly. This is not related to Django ecosystem but to all python packages in general. P.S. Now most of the django plugins probably do not include requirement to Django because they do not want to mess with broken situation in Python packagin. P.S. @BrunoDesthuilliers @aaugustin Sorry if my words are offending you or I sound little more rude. It was not intentional. English is not my native language and probably some times I use inappropriate words. \''

column12: and if then yes that\\\'s a more general issue and no there\\\'s no obvious best solution here. As a side note: one shouldn\\\'t assume that it\\\'s the developper that needs to be reminded that upgrading to a supported & more secure Django release would be a good thing when the stakeholder don\\\'t want to pay for an upgrade despite your warnings
